newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: LME copper seen correcting in near term - Asia trade.
newsitem.headline: LME copper seen correcting in near term - Asia trade.

text.p: Copper prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) were seen edging up in quiet Asian trade on Thursday, but facing a technical correction in the short term, Far East traders said.
Three-month copper was quoted at $2,501/$2,506 a tonne at 0400 GMT, compared with the LME close of $2,500/$2,505 late on Wednesday.
"The copper market appears overbought with the 14-day relative strength index (RSI) at 78.02," said a trader with Samsung Futures in Seoul.
The Samsung trader said current copper prices were likely to meet a technical correction in the near term to ease the market's overbought situation.
The market generally considers an RSI of 70 or more as overbought and 30 or less as oversold.
Copper prices also made a gap between $2,495 and $2,499 on Wednesday and set new one-year high of $2,518 before falling back to $2,506 at the end of the PM kerb.
The cash to threes backwardation also widened to $81/$85 by the end of the kerb from around $70 at the end of business on Tuesday.

LME metal broker Brandeis said in its daily report that the appearance of an island reversal, signalling that prices were over-extended, coupled with the overbought RSI suggested that moves on the upside from this level would be difficult unless prices correct lower first.
Brandeis pegged a support at $2,490/$2,500 and then $2,470.
Meanwhile, with another poor close on the aluminium charts on Wednesday, three-month aluminium prices appeared headed lower and a down channel was becoming established, Brandeis said.
The broker pegged a support for three-month aluminium prices at $1,645/$1,650 and then $,1,625/$1,630.
Borrowing of the nearby dates resulted in the cash/threes spread narrowing to $13/$10 contango at the end of Wednesday's LME kerb, against $19 on the previous day.
Japanese yen-denominated aluminium contracts on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) rose on Thursday in line with the yen's weakness against the dollar.
TOCOM's active April aluminium contract rose in thin trading to 196.0 yen per kg at 0530 GMT, up 4.6 yen from Wednesday's close of 191.4 yen.
"The aluminium prices rose today on TOCOM mainly due to the weak yen against the dollar," said a trader at Japanese broker Ace Koeki Co Ltd in Tokyo.
Three-month zinc prices were barely changed in Asian trade and are expected to decline on a technical correction.
The zinc market also stood in overbought territory with the 14-day RSI at 70.21.
A regional trader said LME stocks for copper and aluminium are expected to decline further on Thursday.
